title: Kant on Space and Time
description: Kant's transcendental idealism posits that space and time are not objective features of things in themselves, but rather subjective features of our mindsâ€”forms of sensibility that structure our experience of the world.

connections.title: Transcendental Aesthetic
connections.description: Kant's investigation of the a priori conditions of human sensibility in the Critique of Pure Reason

connections.title: A Priori Intuition
connections.description: Kant's view that space and time are known through a priori intuition rather than concepts

connections.title: Forms of Sensibility
connections.description: Kant's thesis that space and time are forms of sensibility that structure our experience

connections.title: Ideality of Space and Time
connections.description: Kant's view that space and time are ideal (mind-dependent) rather than real properties of things in themselves

connections.title: Things in Themselves
connections.description: Kant's concept of noumena or objects as they are independent of our perception

connections.title: Transcendental Realism
connections.description: The position Kant rejects that treats space and time as features of things in themselves

connections.title: Newtonian Absolute Framework
connections.description: Newton's conception of absolute space and time that influenced Kant's thinking

connections.title: Leibnizian Relational View
connections.description: Leibniz's relational conception of space and time that Kant sought to overcome

connections.title: Synthetic A Priori Knowledge
connections.description: Kant's notion that knowledge of space and time is synthetic a priori

connections.title: Euclidean Geometry
connections.description: Kant's view that Euclidean geometry is synthetically true a priori because of the nature of spatial intuition

connections.title: Mathematical Cognition
connections.description: Kant's account of how mathematics is possible through pure intuition of space and time

connections.title: Schematism
connections.description: Kant's theory of how concepts are applied to intuitions through temporal schemas
